See https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3328 for byte-code java 8 related stuff.

Just to be clear, I'm not intending to drive a change to Java 8 source and bytecode. Just requiring Java 8 JVM at runtime so we can use dependencies that _do_ use Java 8 bytecode (like newer versions of Jetty and DataSketches).

I would be OK with changing to Java 8 source and bytecode as well if the community thinks it's worth it, but that is not what I meant to propose.
IMO a proposal to switch to Java 8 source should involve some patches that use the new Java 8 features to good effect.
@du00cs @justsmoke there's a few merge conflicts. Do you guys feel this is ready?

@fjy drops should be put on ZK one-at-a-time by the `LoadQueuePeon`, which would mean that you have a bit of a throttle built in there already.  Are you saying that the rate of LoadQueuePeons writing to ZK was able to cause an issue?  If that's the case, then I would suggest that the correct fix would be to add a minimum delay to when the `LoadQueuePeon` writes the next thing on ZK.

I.e. you set that to 100ms or something and the LoadQueuePeon makes sure that at least 100ms has passed before it adds the next thing on ZK?

https://fasterxml.github.io/jackson-databind/javadoc/2.6/com/fasterxml/jackson/databind/SerializationFeature.html#FLUSH_AFTER_WRITE_VALUE explicitly states

`for example when underlying stream is compressing and flush() causes compression state to be flushed (which occurs with some compression codecs).`

Can you verify or refute if you are using compressed or uncompressed streams between the broker and historical?

The numbers in the original post were for uncompressed streams, using a modified version of http-client that allows for compression codec selection:

https://github.com/metamx/http-client/pull/26

Maybe a context flag like `"limitApproximate":"true"`. On top of #1872 this should be doable by enabling the limit push down always when that flag is set, rather than only when pushdown is lossless.

#2864 was about doing this on groupBy v1, but these days it makes more sense to work on groupBy v2. Doing limit pushdown there would involve implementing some kind of continuous sorting and limiting in the merge step, which could take the form of a priority-queue-powered version of BufferGrouper.

@fjy rebased on master
See RoaringBitmap/RoaringBitmap#129

# New interfaces  describe
* Directory  is a container of files . We create files here,open IndexInput for a file to read data we have written,open a IndexOutput for a file to write data into.
* IndexInput  (sorry for @leventov   I have not got a good name ,maybe FileInput or something good ? Ôºåfor now to interpret my solution first,just have this name ,if find a good name ,I will refactor the code later) behaves like the ByteBuffer. We use seek() to move file point, use length() to get the capacity ,use slice() to get a scliced one what needs to be noticed is that the sliced one's  file point will keep on growing compared to its original one,use duplicate() to have a fresh duplicated one
* IndexOutput  a way to write data into a file of the Directory
* RandomAccessInput:  As ` Indexed<T> `needs to random access a file ,this class supply a way to absolue read data from a file. The related methods need to be thread safe. subclasses may override this IndexInput.randomAccess() method for performance reason like what ByteBufferIndexInput class does.
* bytecode format rule : the interface level to restrict data type like int/long/short to use big-endian byte code order. As Druid LongsLong encoding does not restrict byte code order, The LongsLongEncodingWriter and LongsLongEncodingReader class's write long method was specific written using bytes for compatibility . BTW,as Druid's other type byte code order are all big-endian ,why not having a uniform byte code order.
* conventional column smooth file size is Integer.MAX_VALUE. So the interface to convert long to int is considering correctly. I have also noticed the PR #3743 that seems split larger columns into separate smooth files which also observes the Integer.MAX_VALUE rule.
# What have done
* implement a mmap version Directory
* v9 version implemention based on Directory, using a new  DirectoryBasedTmpIOPeon not the TmpFilePeon to wite temp files like .header,.format,.drd and so on while creating directory,bitmap,metrics,timestamp index data. A finally segement Directory will only have .smooth ,meta.smooth,version.bin files.
* remove smooth related files from  java-util bundle ,as these codes  are closely bound up with the processing bundle. 

# What have to do later
* IndexIO has a static  `checkFileSize(File indexFile) ` which needs to have a similar Directory version by considering backward compatibility.
* V9 version's RTree have not refactored.
* legacy version refactor.
*  `ComplexMetricSerde. deserializeColumn(IndexInput indexInput, ColumnBuilder builder) `  needs to be implemented in other bundles besides the processing bundle.
* The old interface has to be refactored using the Directory interface in the IndexIO , IndexMerger  maybe sometime later. This work will affects the calling methods in other bundles.


# Benchmark 
* add a benchmark class:io.druid.benchmark.indexing.IndexMergeDirectoryBenchmark
* here are the benchmark under the linux os with 24 cores :

>
Benchmark                                      (numSegments)  (rollup)  (rowsPerSegment)  (schema)  Mode  Cnt        Score        Error  Units
IndexMergeDirectoryBenchmark.mergeV9                       5      true             75000     basic  avgt   25  9240124.749 ¬± 347646.305  us/op
IndexMergeDirectoryBenchmark.mergeV9                       5     false             75000     basic  avgt   25  9108096.768 ¬± 353987.000  us/op
IndexMergeDirectoryBenchmark.mergeV9Directory              5      true             75000     basic  avgt   25  9123815.002 ¬± 408413.806  us/op
IndexMergeDirectoryBenchmark.mergeV9Directory              5     false             75000     basic  avgt   25  9111214.891 ¬± 353926.469  us/op

üëç

I support having `virtualColumns` being their own layer that is defined by JSON in the top level of the query. FWIW Plywood has always been built on top of that concept (it is called `derivedAttributes`).

I think the most important objective for `virtualColumns` bar none is that they work everywhere, on all query types and in all query constructs. As for the complexity of the API: I think people who make ad-hock queries will opt to use the SQL capabilities and people that are writing software that makes queries programmatically will not see much of a problem.
üëç

@vogievetsky, yes, in my mind it is definitely an objective to make virtual columns work for all the things: selecting, grouping, filtering, and aggregating. With their introduction in #2511 they just work for selecting, this patch makes them work for aggregating, and future patches could make them work for grouping and filtering.
@leventov have you measured the improvement here?
But yes I think all Druid users that have complex filtering needs should consider Roaring.
I think things are much cleaner now after doing a quick read through

@gianm no, I didn't. I don't think improvement is significant, because empty bitmaps in compressed representations (concise and roaring) doesn't take much space and cheap to union with. However for roaring it saves one allocation/merge cycle because roaring doesn't support union (and intersection) of more than 2 bitmaps, for making union of many bitmaps it merges them one-by-one.
@akashdw could you also please remove `bytebuffer-collections` dependency from the root pom?
@leventov Sure, I will create a pr for the pom cleanup.

It looks like post-rebasing this is no longer fixing anything or changing behavior (the new EvalTest passes even on master) but is instead just refactoring the boolean cast code and adding a new test. Still valuable, but I'm going to change the PR title to reflect that.

This patch is still removing the ability to store relative paths in segment metadata, which I know at least one person (@himanshug) has advocated as useful in the past.

@himanshug can you chime in please?

Pushed another commit containing a DimensionSelector for expressions. It doesn't actually work with topN and groupBy, though, since its value cardinality is `CARDINALITY_UNKNOWN` which they can't handle right now.

@gianm I have some following PRs waiting on expression subject. 
- expression-metric-filter (#3755)
- math-virtual-column (in local, not PRed yet)
- virtual-column-as-dimension (in local, not PRed yet)
- etc. (small things)  

inline

Virtual columns:
>- Move VirtualColumn and related classes to their own package.

Could you postpone this till things settled down?

>- Add additional methods to VirtualColumn to support more kinds of selectors and
  to support cycle detection.
> - Add ExpressionVirtualColumn in core, offering math expressions as a virtual column.

This is done in `math-virtual-column`. Could you wait on it?

> - Put cache IDs in VirtualColumnCacheHelper.

good idea.

Queries:
> - Add VirtualColumns to timeseries, topN, and groupBy.

I think this is done in `virtual-column-as-dimension`

Aggregators:
> - Remove the "expression" parameter (replaced by "expression" virtual columns).

I remember this is commented in previous PR. been thinking of replacing `field` with `expression` but this code looks removing `expression`, but ok (we should keep it as was in our version because it's already legacy, for year, for us). 

ColumnSelectorFactory:
> - Change getColumnCapabilities to getNativeType, since that's all anyone was using
  it for, and it's simpler.

good

> - Remove "makeMathExpressionSelector" (replaced by "expression" virtual columns).

This is for making in-line VC which is very useful. but ok, we will keep that in ours. 

Storage adapters:
> - Add virtual column hooks before checking base columns. I think this ordering makes
  more sense than checking base columns first, since it prevents surprises when a
  new base column is added that happens to have the same name as a virtual column.

good

And actually, it's possible to group-by on vc with some limitations(memory pressure), something like things done in `SingleScanTimeDimSelector` because group-by does not rely on cardinality of dimension.

@navis thanks for the feedback. On your points:

>> - Move VirtualColumn and related classes to their own package.

> Could you postpone this till things settled down?

yes, sure, I'll move the existing classes back. I'll still create a "virtual" package for the new classes though since there won't be conflicts there.

>> - Add additional methods to VirtualColumn to support more kinds of selectors and
to support cycle detection.
>> - Add ExpressionVirtualColumn in core, offering math expressions as a virtual column.

> This is done in math-virtual-column. Could you wait on it?

Is your impl substantially different from the one in here? If so, what's different about it? Or, if it's not really different, would the the one in here work for you?

I'm asking because the impl in here is necessary to keep some of the tests working properly, due to removal of makeMathExpressionSelector from ColumnSelectorFactory. If yours is different & better than my impl, could I merge it into this PR and replace my impl?

>> - Remove "makeMathExpressionSelector" (replaced by "expression" virtual columns).

> This is for making in-line VC which is very useful. but ok, we will keep that in ours.

I guessed you were using it for this. I see the feature is useful, but I still prefer to remove it¬†and use explicit virtualColumns since that simplifies the code for column selectors, aggregators, and filters.

Finally, that's a good point about grouping. But I'd like to eventually modify the query engines so that we can control the memory usage. I was thinking of using a bounded memory dictionary with spilling for that (at least for groupBy, which can spill). That's a separate issue though.
Moved VirtualColumn and VirtualColumns back to original locations.

thx @niketh, posted another review.

For this, if we do end up removing makeMathExpressionSelector from ColumnSelectorFactory (which I am in favor of for reasons mentioned at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3758#issuecomment-265488351) then I would also prefer to do filtering on expression through virtual columns as well.

The reasons are basically the same:

- that is a more composable approach that requires fewer parts of Druid to know what a "math expression" is.
- that would make filtering on any other projection/virtual column work too.

If so I think that to support metrics filtering, the way to do that would be to support filtering on virtual columns in general. @navis does that direction work for you?

I think druid community prefers making new PR trade-marked with "metamarket" or "imply" rather than bothering reviewing awkward PR from unknown party because this is the third time happened in this year I've met, which I've never experienced in three year in other community. Ok, whatsoever, you can do anything in your preferred way.

Hi @navis, I believe @gianm is bringing up some reasonable points with regards to this PR that is worth a discussion. I understand there's been some overlap in the work the two of you have been doing with regards to virtual columns, but I think through the discussion we can work towards resolving the conflict. The purpose of these discussions, which are a part of almost every large PR, is to make sure that as best we can, we are making good technical discussions for the project. With that in mind, can you reopen this PR?
@jon-wei thank you for merging this. Looks like 0.9.3 will be the first release we will be able to use without modifications :)
Tagged Discuss due to open questions about how to move forward with the subsystem (see also #3755 and https://groups.google.com/d/topic/druid-development/_Sd78s7yU5U/discussion).

@navis, my PR #3758 was just about a day of work and I have no issue with tossing it if the community thinks that is best. Trying to build consensus on community opinion was the purpose of starting the druid-development list discussion. I just raised that PR to try to show what I'm thinking in a concrete way. I respect that you've spent much more time on this area than I have and I want to find something that works for everyone.

To me the big question right now is for _expressions_, and it's whether they should be a concept that is only accessible through the virtual column subsystem, or should they be a concept that aggs, filters, storage adapters etc are also aware of.

In general the place I'm coming from is trying to make sure we develop the various subsystems in Druid such that they can work well together. In the past, we've had a lot of problems related to certain subsystems not working properly with others (for example, not all filters working with filtered aggregators, not all aggregators working on outer queries of nested groupBys, etc) and generally we have had made progress on those issues by simplifying interfaces and reducing the number and complexity of touch points. So I'm looking to do something similar here, and I think that running expressions through virtual columns will help simplify things and reduce bugs.

I hope that makes sense and I hope we can reach consensus quickly on https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/_Sd78s7yU5U.

@navis would you mind PRing "virtual-column-as-dimension" so we can see what direction you are proposing there? In this PR, not much progress is being made on treating them as dimensions‚Ä¶¬†there's a dimension selector maker on VirtualColumn but it's not actually usable by the query engines or for filtering as-is. I had some vague ideas there but nothing really concrete.

In the end I'm happy throwing away most of my PR although it has some things I would like to keep:

- the additional validations on VirtualColumns, including cycle detection, this helps fail fast
- using VirtualColumns as the serde type instead of List<VirtualColumn>, this helps fail fast too
- checking VirtualColumns before base columns, this makes behavior less surprising
- removing expressions from ColumnSelectorFactory and ValueMatcherFactory, this simplifies implementations (pending further discussion?)

To me only the last one seems really controversial.
